abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. Among the lessons
            learned, it is suggested that communities were capable of
            demanding, and maintaining services, as well as making
            contributions to capital costs, and operation and
            maintenance. Most importantly, the project proved that the
            demand-driven approach, when accompanied by adequate
            information campaigns, outlining the technical options,
            associated costs, and, an effective financial policy
            implementation, lays the ground for community involvement,
            and their commitment to sustain development. Hence, review
            of the first year of the project, concluded that District
            staff needed to be selected more on the basis of their
            communication, and management skills, rather than technical
            skills alone, and, should be selected in response to their
            demand for participation. The project also showed the
            importance of not only transferring decision-making, but
            also resources, if decentralization, and local
            accountability are to be achieved, since community, and
            district-level contracting establishes a commercial link,
            allowing the community to develop procurement capacity.
            Nonetheless, donor coordination remains a challenge, since
            the Community Water and Sanitation Agency, must continue to
            balance each donor reporting requirements, with those of the Government.
